subclusters.subcluster_name: ROS Hormesis and Adaptive Stress Response Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ROS causing cumulative molecular damage leading to aging, representing the core oxidative damage concept.
Describes ROS as damaging agents accumulating molecular damage and decline in repair capacity, fitting classical oxidative damage.
Emphasizes ROS-induced oxidative damage to biomolecules causing aging and age-related diseases, aligning with classical damage.
Highlights ROS overproduction and antioxidant defense decline causing oxidative damage and aging, fitting classical damage theme.
Focuses on free radical imbalance causing oxidative damage driving aging, consistent with classical oxidative damage theory.
Describes ROS as mediators of aging via cumulative damage, with genetic and pathway involvement, fitting classical damage accumulation.
Focuses on oxidative damage accumulation and antioxidant enzymes mitigating damage, consistent with classical oxidative damage theory.
Emphasizes ROS accumulation causing damage and importance of MnSOD in mitigating oxidative stress, fitting classical damage theme.
Focuses on ROS overproduction causing damage and antioxidant vitamin C mitigating oxidative stress, consistent with classical damage.
Supports oxidative damage accumulation by ROS as a causal factor in aging, based on model organism evidence, fitting classical damage.
Combines oxidative damage with glycoxidative damage mechanisms, focusing on metabolic damage accumulation in aging.
Focuses on glycation-induced oxidative damage impairing antioxidant enzymes, linking glycoxidation to oxidative stress and aging.
Describes oxidative distress causing protein oxidation and impaired degradation, emphasizing molecular damage accumulation.
Details hydroxyl radical generation, lipid peroxidation, DNA rearrangements causing premature aging, fitting oxidative molecular damage.
Focuses on mitochondrial ROS production and dysfunction as primary drivers of oxidative damage and aging.
Emphasizes mitochondrial dysfunction leading to ROS accumulation and oxidative damage in skeletal muscle aging.
Links mitochondrial enzyme mutation causing oxygen hypersensitivity and oxidative damage to aging, highlighting mitochondrial role.
Describes ROS-AMPK signaling and mitochondrial quality control mechanisms improving mitochondrial function and longevity.
Focuses on mitohormesis via mitochondrial calcium regulation and ROS signaling activating stress responses for longevity.
Links RAAS-induced ROS production to oxidative stress and aging, with mitochondrial ROS as key mediators.
Focuses on oxidative stress driving cardiovascular aging via ROS damage and metabolic dysfunction, implicating mitochondria.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: ROS Hormesis and Adaptive Stress Response Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes ROS hormesis where low ROS levels activate protective pathways enhancing longevity.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: ROS Hormesis and Adaptive Stress Response Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on hormesis via ROS signaling activating SKN-1 and DAF-16 pathways to extend lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: ROS Hormesis and Adaptive Stress Response Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes antioxidant defenses and stress response pathways modulated by ROS to influence lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: ROS Hormesis and Adaptive Stress Response Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ROS metabolism in motorneurons affecting lifespan via signaling and damage, fitting ROS signaling and hormesis.
Emphasizes interplay between oxidative stress and inflammation driving aging, with sex differences and immune involvement.
Focuses on chronic oxidative and inflammatory stress (inflammaging) and immune system role in aging.
Describes linked oxidative and inflammatory stress impairing neuroimmune communication, driving aging.
Links oxidative stress to Alzheimer's disease pathology and general aging, highlighting oxidative-inflammation mechanisms.
Describes oxidative inhibition of autophagy via thiol oxidation, linking oxidative stress to impaired cellular clearance and aging.
